title: Spectra - could 18 eV photon interact with gs atom

content.question: The diagram shows the energy levels of a hypothetical atom. The energy state at <math alttext="0 electron volts" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>eV</mtext></math> corresponds to an ionized atom, and the <math alttext="negative 14 electron volts" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>−</mo><mn>14</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>eV</mtext></math> state is the atom’s ground state. For an atom in the ground state, could a photon of energy <math alttext="18 electron volts" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>18</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>eV</mtext></math> interact with the atom? What reasoning supports the answer?

choices.label: Yes. The photon’s energy is greater than the atom’s binding energy.

Yes. There are two energy states with energies that sum to <math alttext="negative 18 electron volts" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>−</mo><mn>18</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>eV</mtext></math>.
No. An atom in its lowest-energy state cannot interact with photons.

No. There is no energy difference between any two states that is equal to <math alttext="18 electron volts" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>18</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>eV</mtext></math>.

content.answer: Yes. The photon’s energy is greater than the atom’s binding energy.
